rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:1
rsbNotes.text: 13:1 twenty-third year of Joash . . . reigned seventeen years. That is, 814–798 b.c.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:2
rsbNotes.text: 13:2 the sins of Jeroboam. See note 1 Kin. 12:30.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:3
rsbNotes.text: 13:3 Ben-hadad the son of Hazael. That is, Ben-hadad III. For Ben-hadad I, see 1 Kin. 15:18–21; for Ben-hadad II, see 1 Kin. 20:1 note; 2 Kin. 6:24; 8:7.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:5
rsbNotes.text: 13:5 gave Israel a savior. Much as in the time of the judges (Judg. 2:16–23), God provides temporary help from the Syrian onslaught. The deliverer is not named.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:6
rsbNotes.text:
13:6 the sins of the house of Jeroboam. See note 1 Kin. 12:30.

Asherah. This object was set up by Ahab (1 Kin. 16:33) and apparently was left untouched by Jehu’s reforms (2 Kin. 10:18–28).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:7
rsbNotes.text: 13:7 fifty horsemen and ten chariots and ten thousand footmen. The king is left with a large number of infantry, but only a very few chariots. This crippled his ability to react quickly to a military crisis.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:8
rsbNotes.text: 13:8 Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel. See note 1 Kin. 11:41.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:10
rsbNotes.text: 13:10 the thirty-seventh year of Joash. That is, 798 b.c. Jehoash reigned 798–782 b.c.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:11
rsbNotes.text: 13:11 the sins of Jeroboam. See note 1 Kin. 12:30.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:12
rsbNotes.text: 13:12 Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel. See note 1 Kin. 11:41.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:13
rsbNotes.text: 13:13 Jeroboam. Jeroboam II ruled from 793–753 b.c., including eleven years as co-regent with his father Jehoash. Jeroboam began his independent reign when Jehoash died in 782 b.c. See 14:23–29.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:14
rsbNotes.text:
13:14 My father. See note 2:12.

The chariots of Israel and its horsemen. Earlier, Elisha used this expression of Elijah; now Jehoash applies the compliment to Elisha.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:17
rsbNotes.text:
13:17 eastward. This window opened toward the region controlled by Syria (10:32, 33).

the arrow of victory over Syria. The symbolic action is a prophecy that Jehoash himself will fulfill.

Aphek. See note 1 Kin. 20:26.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:18
rsbNotes.text: 13:18 and stopped. Somehow Jehoash failed to perceive the inner meaning of what the prophet was urging him to do. Elisha considered that Jehoash was clearly guilty for his lack of enthusiasm.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:20
rsbNotes.text: 13:20 Elisha died. Presumably Elisha died of old age.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:23
rsbNotes.text: 13:23 because of His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Divine commitment is steadfast and eternal (cf. 1 Kin. 18:36).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:24
rsbNotes.text: 13:24 Ben-hadad. That is, Ben-hadad III (v. 3 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 13:25
rsbNotes.text: 13:25 Three times Joash defeated him. Fulfilling the last prophecy of Elisha (v. 19), the victories of Joash stopped the Syrian expansion. Later, Jeroboam II would also defeat the Syrians (14:25).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:1
rsbNotes.text: 14:1 In the second year of Joash. That is, 796 b.c.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:3
rsbNotes.text:
14:3 he did what was right in the eyes of the Lord. He followed the laws of the covenant (1 Kin. 2:3 note).

yet not like David his father. See note 1 Kin. 11:4.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:4
rsbNotes.text: 14:4 the high places were not removed. Amaziah is one of several kings of Judah praised by the author, but his praise is qualified because Amaziah tolerated worship at the hilltop shrines (1 Kin. 3:2 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:5
rsbNotes.text: 14:5 struck down his servants. See 12:20, 21.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:7
rsbNotes.text:
14:7 struck down ten thousand Edomites. This major victory temporarily reversed earlier losses (cf. 8:20–22; 2 Chr. 25:11, 12).

Valley of Salt. Probably this is the salt flats south of the Dead Sea (cf. 2 Sam. 8:13; Ps. 60:title).

Sela. The Septuagint (Old Testament Greek translation) identifies Sela (meaning “rock” in Hebrew) as Petra (meaning “rock” in Greek), located along the Rift Valley about fifty miles south of the Dead Sea. Some modern scholars place it in northern Edomite territory near Bozrah (Judg. 1:36).

to this day. This phrase reflects a time before the Jews were taken captive to Babylon (1 Kin. 8:8 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:8
rsbNotes.text: 14:8 Jehoash. See 13:10–25.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:9
rsbNotes.text: 14:9 A thistle. The northern kingdom was larger and more powerful than the southern kingdom (1 Kin. 14:30; 15:16, 17 and notes). In this fable (cf. Judg. 9:8–15) the little thistle (Amaziah) thinks it is equal to a cedar of Lebanon (Jehoash) only to be trampled underfoot.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:11
rsbNotes.text: 14:11 Beth-shemesh. A city fifteen miles west of Jerusalem (1 Kin. 4:9).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:13
rsbNotes.text:
14:13 Jehoash . . . captured Amaziah. Jehoash probably brought Amaziah back to Samaria (v. 14). Amaziah was forced to stay there until the death of Jehoash (v. 17).

Ephraim Gate. This main gate was in the north wall (Neh. 8:16; 12:39).

Corner Gate. At the northwest angle of the wall (2 Chr. 26:9; Jer. 31:38; Zech. 14:10).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:15
rsbNotes.text: 14:15 Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel. See note 1 Kin. 11:41.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:16
rsbNotes.text: 14:16 Jeroboam. Jeroboam II, who ruled from 793–753 b.c. (vv. 23–29).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:18
rsbNotes.text: 14:18 Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah. See note 1 Kin. 11:41.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:19
rsbNotes.text: 14:19 Lachish. An important city of Judah fifteen miles west of Hebron.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:21
rsbNotes.text: 14:21 sixteen years old. Probably Azariah was made king during his father’s absence, and the reigns of father and son overlapped for many years (vv. 13, 17).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:22
rsbNotes.text: 14:22 Elath. A seaport on the Gulf of Aqaba, Elath was first used by Solomon to foster sea trade with other nations (1 Kin. 9:26–28). Because Amaziah defeated Edom (v. 7), his son Azariah was able to rebuild Elath and again use it as a Judean port (cf. 1 Kin. 22:47–49; 2 Kin. 8:20–22; 16:6).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:23
rsbNotes.text:
14:23 In the fifteenth year of Amaziah. That is, 782 b.c., the beginning of Jeroboam’s independent reign.

Jeroboam. That is, Jeroboam II. For the reign of Jeroboam I, see 1 Kin. 11:26–14:19.

forty-one years. That is, 793–753 b.c. It is likely that Jeroboam II was co-regent with his father Jehoash for eleven years at the start of his reign (Introduction to 1 Kings: Characteristics and Themes).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:24
rsbNotes.text: 14:24 the sins of Jeroboam. See note 1 Kin. 12:30. Politically and economically, Jeroboam II was one of the most successful monarchs in the entire history of the northern kingdom (v. 25). He forced the Syrians to retreat from Damascus into central Syria. He also expanded Israelite territory toward the Dead Sea.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:25
rsbNotes.text:
14:25 Lebo-hamath. This area was the northernmost part of Israel (Num. 13:21; 34:7–9; 1 Kin. 8:65 note).

Sea of the Arabah. That is, the Dead Sea (Josh. 3:16; 12:3). Jeroboam expanded Israel’s territory to the south on the eastern side of the Jordan, the lands of Ammon and Moab. Jeroboam II controlled more land than any previous northern king (cf. Amos 6:14).

Jonah the son of Amittai. See Introduction to Jonah.

Gath-hepher. About fourteen miles west of the southern part of the Sea of Chinneroth (Galilee). See Josh. 19:13.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:27
rsbNotes.text: 14:27 blot out the name. In the ancient Near East names were erased from inscriptions as a sign of rejection or loss of power (Ex. 32:32, 33; Deut. 9:14; 29:20).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:28
rsbNotes.text:
14:28 Damascus. The capital of Syria.

Hamath. That is, “Lebo-hamath.” See note on v. 25.

Judah. David and Solomon had controlled both Damascus and Hamath (2 Sam. 8:6; 1 Kin. 8:65; 2 Chr. 8:3).

Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel. See note 1 Kin. 11:41.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Kgs 14:29
rsbNotes.text: 14:29 Zechariah. On the reign of Zechariah, see 15:8–12.
